title: Experimental Station
description: Danny Burke from Experimental Station will talk about the 61st Street Farmers Market including their food access programs around food stamps, value incentives, table counts and consumer behavior within the context of food justice on the south and west sides of Chicago.

title: Open Hack Session
description: No presentations this week - just come to build, share, and learn about civic tech!

title: Affordable Care Act Outreach App
description:
Dominique Williams and Josh Kalov will present on the Affordable Care Act Outreach App built by Smart Chicago Collaborative for LISC-Chicago as part of the Civic Works Project.

Through their efforts, LISC helped to enroll 2,975 Chicagoans for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act.

links.name: Hack Night Live: Civic Works Project's ACA Outreach App

title: Transit Future and Large Lots
description:
For our 100th Hack Night, we will have two presentations:

Ed Oser and Nick Doiron (https://twitter.com/mapmeld) will present Transit Future, a vision of an expanded Chicago public transportation system led by the Center for Neighborhood Technology and Active Transportation Alliance with a visualization by Open City.

AND

Demond Drummer from Teamwork Englewood will talk about LargeLots.org, an app built by DataMade and LISC Chicago for navigating the City's program for selling vacant lots on the South Side for $1.

links.name: Hack Night Live: Transit Future and LargeLots.org

title: The Chicago Tribune Elections Website
description: David Eads returns to the hack night to talk about his work on the Chicago Tribune Elections Website. He'll go over their use of the new Reuters election data service and how they integrated the content in to print.

title: Divvy Data Winners
description: The 5 winners of the Divvy Data Challenge will be announced with demos to follow.

title: Daniel Hertz - Zoning in Chicago
description: Urban policy blogger Daniel Hertz will talk about the downsides of low-density zoning in Chicago, and how he uses open zoning data to understand the built environment.

title: Chicago CIO Brenna Berman on Procurement
description:
City of Chicago CIO Brenna Berman will host a Q&A session on technology procurement, similar to last month's OpenGov Chicago meetup (here's the meeting notes).

The City is looking for ways to improve the procurement process and lower barriers to entry for small and medium businesses. If you have questions, feedback or suggestions on how Chicago buys technology, this is your chance speak up!

links.name: OpenGov Chicago Live: IT Procurement & The City of Chicago
OIT Procurement & The City of Chicago Meeting Notes
Daniel X. O'Neil: Some Thoughts Toward the Maturation of the Civic Innovation Sector of the Technology Industry
WBEZ Tech Shift: Open data and government websites
Hack Night Live: CIO Brenna Berman talks Procurement

title: FWD.us
description: Bojan Francuz from FWD.us will talk about the data, tools and processes they use to advocate for policies like immigration reform.

links.name: OpenGov Hack Night: Apps that Advocate

title: Expunge.io
description: Cathy Deng will talk about Expunge.io, a guide to help youth in Cook County erase their juvenile arrest and/or court records through the legal process of juvenile expungement.

title: Cartografika
description: Adam Jentleson, Jose Alarcon, and Taylor McKinley from Cartografika will tell us about their use of open data to craft stunning maps of Chicago's urban fabric - and those of cities around the world.

title: Divvy Data II
description:
Following up on the successful Divvy Data hack night last summer, Steven Vance and other developers will share what they have created to analyze station locations, track rides, and use hardware to know bike/station availability.

Elliot Greenberger from Divvy will also be making a special announcement.

links.name: Capital Bikeshare Hackers Pedal Their Wares at Mobility Lab

title: The Handbuilt City
description: Nat Zorach from The Handbuilt City will discuss how they use Fundrise to spur the development of affordable housing in Gary, IN and St Louis, MO.

title: Get Covered Illinois
description: Charles Watkins from Get Covered Illinois will discuss the Affordable Care Act and its implementation here in Illinois.

links.name: Get Covered Illinois at OpenGov Hack Night

title: GeoGit
description: Nick Doiron will present GeoGit, a way for cities and civic hackers to publish their data and make maps that change over time, like this one of Chicago's Divvy stations.

title: CivicLab
description: Benjamin Sugar will introduce us to CivicLab, a new space that has opened up in Chicago to encourage 'civic making.' He'll also touch on the intersection of civic media and it's relationship to activism and community organizing.

title: 2013 Year in Review
description: For the last hack night of 2013, Christopher Whitaker and Derek Eder will showcase some open gov highlights from the past year.

title: Chicago Park District Data
description: Ed Rynearson and Patrick Callahan from the Chicago Park District will talk about open data on Chicago parks, as well as some app ideas they'd like some feedback an help on.

title: Chicago Open Data Hidden in Plain Sight
description:
While our local governments continue to do an amazing job of publishing to their open data portals, many datasets still exist solely on obscure websites most of us don't know about.

Forest Gregg will talk about some of these lesser known, but highly useful, open data sources available in Chicago including river pollution, financial interest statements, schools and more.

This is part of an ongoing hack night exercise to publicly document Chicago's open data.

links.name: Other Chicago open data - Google doc

title: Geeks Getting Involved in Disaster Response
description: Lisha Sterling from Geeks Without Bounds will talk about organizations and projects that exist to help out in crisis situations, and show us ways that developers can help out when disaster strikes.

title: RedEye Homicide Data
description: Tracy Swartz will talk about her work at RedEye Tracking homicides in Chicago as well as the underlying data they collect and release.

links.name: News Apps tutorial on mapping with Fusion Tables

title: Open Hack Session
description: No presenters - just come ready to build, chat and learn with other civic hackers, government do-gooders, and curious citizens!

title: Tarbell
description: David Eads from the Chicago Tribune News Apps team will walk us through Tarbell, a tool that makes it easy for developers to make lightweight and beautiful websites powered by Google Docs.

title: The City of Chicago Data Dictionary
description: Tom Schenk will discuss the recently launched Chicago Data Dictionary, a website that serves as a single, comprehensive database catalog for the City of Chicago and City of Chicago sister agencies. The City has released the underlying code for this dictionary as open source, titled Metalicious.

links.name: City of Chicago Launches the First Comprehensive, Public Data Dictionary - Smart Chicago

title: The Bike Index
description: Seth Herr will be talking about the Bike Index, an open source bike registry to fight bike theft. Herr & co just had super successful Kickstarter campaign.

title: Center for Neighborhood Technology Hackathon III
description: Part III of the Center for Neighborhood Technology Hackathon

title: Center for Neighborhood Technology Hackathon II
description: Part II of the Center for Neighborhood Technology Hackathon

title: Center for Neighborhood Technology Hackathon I
description:
We're having a joint event with the Center for Neighborhood Technology. CNT is doing their annual Urban Sustainability Apps Competition, where community activists and app developers will work together to build tools to that make Chicago neighborhoods more sustainable, both environmentally and economically.

The main event is a weekend hackathon from Oct 18th-20th, but teams will form and start working at the hack night this week and next. (Of course, you don't have to participate in CNT's hackathon to show up!)

title: Chicago Works for You
description: Chris Gansen will demo Chicago Works for You, a citywide dashboard by Smart Chicago that displays ward-by-ward views of city services in Chicago. Click here for more info on the app, and here for how it was made. The app's github repo is here.

links.name: Hack Night Live: Chicago Works for You - Smart Chicago

title: Open Hack Session
description: No presenters - just come ready to build, chat and learn with other civic hackers, government do-gooders, and curious citizens!

title: Smart Cities and Simulation
description: Matthew Shaxted will share recent projects that investigate smart cities using data analysis, webGL visualization and agent-based simulation.

links.name: OpenGov Hack Night: Smarter Cities using Data Visualization - Smart Chicago

title: Go To School!
description:
Tom Kompare will discuss his experience building Go To School, an app developed built with volunteer labor in partnership with Chicago Public Schools to help parents get their kids to school safely and on time.

We will also discuss the data that CPS makes available, and how it can be used to make other useful apps for Chicagoans.

links.name: Hack Night Live: Go To School and CPS Data - Smart Chicago

title: Data Science for Social Good
description:
Tom Plagge and Juan-Pablo Velez will give a brief retrospective of the Data Science for Social Good summer fellowship program at UChicago where students with CS and statistics backgrounds work on real-world projects with governments and nonprofits.

The fellowship wrapped up last Friday, and Tom and Juan will share results from projects involving the CTA, Chicago Streets and Sanitation, the Cook County Land Bank, and Northshore Hospital.

links.name: Data Science Fellowship for Social Good Demos - Smart Chicago

title: Englewood Codes
description: Demond Drummer of Teamwork Englewood will talk about lessons learned and what's next for Englewood Codes, a Kickstarter and After School Matters funded project where 25 teens from the Englewood community spent the summer learning HTML, CSS and JavaScript and hacking around with the Raspberry Pi.

links.name: Englewood Codes Demo Day is Tonight - Smart Chicago

title: Department of Labor App Challenge
description: Matt Bruce with the Chicago Community Trust and Restaurant Opportunities Centers United will talk about the US Labor Department's app challenge for creating a smartphone app that integrates the department's publicly available enforcement data with consumer ratings, geo-positioning, and other relevant data sets. More details here.

title: DataMandering
description: John Fahrenbach will talk about his Datamandering project, an online tool for demystifying the gerrymandering process with open data.

title: Food Inspection App by Hoy
description: Fernando Diaz and Wilberto Morales from Hoy will demo their new food inspection app: Eat Safe. Come ready to talk about food safety data!

title: Mining 311 Calls
description: One of the Data Science for Social Good teams will talk their work data mining 311 calls and what they're learning about Chicago's neighborhoods.

title: Divvy Trip Planner
description:
Following up from the Hack Night on July 2nd, Adam and Andrew from BGL Consulting will talk about their Divvy trip planner for iOS, as well as an open source DivvyAPI wrapper for creating iPhone apps with Divvy data.

We'll also get a follow-up on the AT&T Hackathon from this weekend and discuss the projects that came out of it.

links.name: New iOS app offers most advanced Divvy route directions - Steven Can Plan

title: Open Hack Session
description: No presenters - just come ready to build, chat and learn with other civic hackers, government do-gooders, and curious citizens!

title: Divvy Data!
description: Steven Vance of Streetsblog Chicago will give an overview of Divvy, Chicago's new bike share program. We'll look in to the open data that is currently available, and the apps that are possible with it. Let's hack some bike share data!

links.name: 4 days after Divvy launch, an app prototype and an API presented at OpenGov Hack Night - Smart Chicago
Divvy Data From the First Weekend and Beyond - Streetsblog Chicago

title: Data Potluck #9: Data Science for Social Good
description: The University of Chicago is doing a Data Science for Social Good fellowship this summer. They've brought 36 aspiring data scientist to Chicago to work on data science projects with city government, federal agencies, and nonprofits from throughout the country. The fellowship is funded by Google chairman Eric Schmidt and is funded by former chief data scientist for the Obama 2012 campaign Rayid Ghani.

title: Checkbook NYC, Learning Fusion Tables
description:
New York City recently released Checkbook NYC, a transparency app that shows the city's budgets, contracts, and payrolls. They also took the unprecedented step of open sourcing the code, and our our friend Karl Fogel helped them do it. Karl will talk about the project, the backstory of how it was opened, and his plans to stand it up in Chicago.

Following on last week's git tutorial, Derek Eder will be teaching interested people the basics of making maps with Google Fusion Tables. Always wanted to learn? Now's your chance.

title: Intro to Git and Github
description: In addition to working on civic tech projects, Derek is going to be leading an intro to Git and Github tutorial for folks who want to learn.

title: Followup from the National Day of Civic Hacking
Gearing up for the National Day of Civic Hacking
Open Source Licenses, Transparency Camp '13 Takaways
Sunlight Foundation, Illinois Department of Employment Security
Getting Started with Open Street Maps
Chicago Architecture Foundation Big Data Exhibit, LocalData
Sunlight Foundation, Cook County Jail Scraper
State CIO Visit, CPS Tiers Update
Open Hack Session
description: First Tuesday session.

title: Open Hack Session
description: First Event at 1871.

title: The First Hack Night
description: The first Chi Hack Night was hosted at Webitects and attended by Derek Eder, Juan-Pablo Velez, Scott Robbin and Tom Kompare.
